case_vignette: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on his face and scalp. He reports that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having this itchy rash on my face and scalp that keeps coming back for the past three months.
Have you noticed any specific triggers that seem to cause the rash to appear or worsen?
Yes, it seems to happen after I use a new shaving cream I started trying out five months ago.
Do you notice any other symptoms accompanying the rash, such as fever, joint pain, or muscle aches?
No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms like that.
Do you have a history of allergies or atopic conditions like asthma or eczema?
I haven't mentioned any history of allergies or atopic conditions.
Understood. Have you tried stopping the use of the new shaving cream to see if the rash improves?
I haven't mentioned trying that.
Has the rash spread to any other areas of your body besides your face and scalp?
The rash has also appeared near the hairline of my scalp and there are greasy yellow scales at the edges of my eyelids.
Given the description of your symptoms, do you also experience flaking or dandruff-like scaling on your scalp?
Yes, there are greasy yellow scales at the hairline of my scalp.
Does the rash improve with any over-the-counter treatments or home remedies you have tried?
I haven't mentioned trying any over-the-counter treatments or home remedies.
Are the affected areas on your scalp and face red and greasy as well as itchy?
Yes, the areas with the rash are itchy, and the scales near my eyelids are greasy.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic dermatitis
